bioghist.p: Among the exemplary collections of the Free Library of Philadelphia is the Print and Picture Collection. Spanning the graphic arts from 1493 to the present time, the Free Library's Fine Art Prints and Photographs collection includes thousands of images. Initially representing only Philadelphia artists, the collection has been extended to include early masters as well as renowned modern printmakers and photographers.

scopecontent.p: This extensive graphic collection consists of posters and placards produced during World War I and prior to and during World War II. Printed by the U.S. Government, governments of Britain, France and other European countries (excluding Germany or Italy), as well as by non-governmental institutions, the posters exhort civilians and servicemen to support the war effort. Subjects of the posters include war bonds and relief funds; recruitment; safety and health; food, energy, and materials conservation; the Red Cross; women's war efforts; home defense; industrial production; and general patriotic themes. Some of the artists were prominent painters and illustrators of the time, including Ben Shahn and Norman Rockwell. The items in the collection vary in size from small placards to very large wall posters. Most of the posters are in English, but there are also posters in French, Polish, Russian, and other languages. The bulk of the posters are from World War I.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
